results.title: Ginger Meggs
results.brief_description: The famous characters of Australia’s most loved comic strip are brought to life in this full-length movie. Tracing the mischievous antics of Ginger Meggs, his friends and foes, the film is a series of vividly visual misadventures as “Meggsie” and his gang create havoc and uproar through their larrikin ways of dodging the law and, more often than not, plunging headfirst into trouble.

results.title: Ginger and Fred = Ginger e Fred
results.creator_credit: Produzioni Europee Associati, Alberto Grimaldi and Federico Fellini
results.brief_description: Director Federico Fellini gently lampoons the world of television show-business in this film. Amelia and Pippo are a pair of aging celebrity impersonators who were a successful cabaret act imitating Ginger Rogers and Fred Astair. Neither one has been successful in other endeavours, and they jump at the chance of recreating their performance on a popular TV show. In the studio they find themselves surrounded by grotesque characters and treated contemptuously. Despite these disappointments however, they recall their once familiar routine and enjoy a brief moment of fame and triumph. In Italian with English subtitles. Cast includes Giulietta Masina and Marcello Mastroianni.

results.title: Gina Jeffreys: somebody's daughter the story so far
results.brief_description: This video offers an insight into the background, aspirations, influences, thoughts and dreams of country singer Gina Jeffreys. Born and raised in Toowoomba, Gina moved away from her family to settle in Sydney and further her musical career which began when she won the Star Maker award in 1991 (although she does have fond memories of busking at the local Mexican restaurant). Since then Gina has been awarded the Golden Guitar at Tamworth for Best Female Vocalist three years in a row. Gina relates memories of her rise to fame and footage is provided from the launch of her latest album, “Somebody’s daughter”. Full music clips are provided of “Dancin’ with Elvis”, “Josephine” and “I haven’t got a heart”.

results.title: Gimme some truth: the making of John Lennon's "Imagine" album
results.brief_description: In May 1971, in Ascot, England, John Lennon and Yoko Ono recorded the classic “Imagine” album in their own private studio. This documentary encapsulates the trials and tribulations of producing an album, from the direction and guidance of Phil Spector and his sound technicians to the collaboration of the musicians including George Harrison, Nicky Hopkins, and Klaus Voorman. During the making of “Imagine”, John and Yoko took the unusual step of filming every aspect of the recording sessions. Enriching this documentary is footage from that filming including intimate moments between John and Yoko, life and friends outside the Studio, and a wonderful glimpse into the fashion and culture of 1971. Famous faces that pass across the screen include Jack Nicholson, Andy Warhol, Miles Davis and a very young Julian Lennon. Commentary throughout the film by John and Yoko, John’s wonderful wry sense of humor and not least of all, the studio performances by John Lennon of the songs that make up this memorable classic album, all add to a must see documentary.

results.title: Gimme shelter
results.brief_description: In 1969 the Rolling Stones were arguably the most popular and the most seductive band in the world. Originally begun as a documentary of their American tour, ‘Gimme Shelter’ turned into something quite different when at the end of the tour the Stones organised a free concert at Altamont in California. Hundreds of thousands of young people on hallucinogenic drugs turned up, the local Hell’s Angels were hired as bouncers and security, and before the end of the night, four people were dead, including a young black teenager whose murder by the Hell’s Angels is horrifically caught on film. In hindsight, the Altamont free concert came to be seen as the death of “the summer of love”, that innocent time in popular culture where it was believed that rock music, drugs, and youth culture would usher in a new age of peace and non-violence in American culture. The Maysles brothers took their raw footage and then had the Stones watching the events in the editing studio. What we as an audience then become witness to is a group of young men coming to terms with the full horror and limitation of their status as “rock gods”. Although ‘Gimme Shelter’ ultimately enters history as a document detailing the bitter come-down of rock and roll, it also captures the exciting and erotic magic of the young Rolling Stones on stage, as well as footage of Tina Turner, Grace Slick and a host of psychedelic bands from the late sixties. The intimacy the directors had with the band can be gauged by the wonderful footage the Maysles brothers were able to take of the Stones at their worst as well as their best, including a mesmerizing sequence in the recording studio where they listen to their work on the “Sticky Fingers” sessions.

results.title: Gilmore girl
results.brief_description: Moving house is one thing but changing schools is a totally different story. Anda talks about her journey to find her place, of moving house from St Albans to Yarraville and eventually back to St Albans, of leaving the old and familiar behind and having to confront a new school, new friends and an unfamiliar environment.

results.title: Gilly, the salamander
results.creator_credit: Coronet Instructional Films and Mimi Lampert
results.brief_description: Because only his egg escaped a catfish massacre, Gilly grows up thinking he is really a too-long frog. Finally, unable to bear the unkind jibes of the frogs, he leaves the pond to find his true identity. When he returns he meets Sally Salamander, who tells him the facts of his life. This film uses the story about a salamander to motivate the practice of language skills and to encourage young children to share experiences in learning about themselves. For primary grades.

results.title: Spotlights: Gillian Armstrong
results.brief_description: An Australian feature film and documentary director who specialises in period drama. Her films often feature female perspectives and protagonists. Gillian discusses female directors and also mentions My Brilliant Career (1979), which features in the New Wave section of Moving Australia.

constellations_primary.name: Brilliant careers (Gillian Armstrong)
constellations_primary.description: Gillian Armstrong's feature film debut not only helped launch her own acclaimed career, but those of the actors as well.

results.description: An Australian feature film and documentary director who specialises in period drama, Gillian Armstrong’s work often features female perspectives and protagonists. Gillian discusses female directors as well as her groundbreaking debut My Brilliant Career (1979), which features in Moving Australia.

results.title: Gillian's Story
results.brief_description: Leanne Wagner pays tribute to her remarkable sister Gillian who has had to battle with Sturge-Weber syndrome, epilepsy, schizophrenia, glaucoma and an intellectial disability.

results.title: Gill Armstrong
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Film Makers”.
Michael Carlton interviews Australian film-maker Gillian Armstrong about her motivations for making films, and discusses some of her productions, in particular “My brilliant career”.
